summary: This is a court order from November 2021 regarding the authentication of Government Exhibit 52 in the Epstein case. The order directs the Government to reply to the Defendant's argument that 'Employee-1' cannot authenticate the exhibit because a former employee allegedly removed the document before Employee-1 began working for Epstein. It also sets deadlines for proposed redactions to motion papers.

persons.name: Employee-1
persons.context: Referenced as the individual the Government proposes to authenticate Government Exhibit 52, but the Defendant argues Employee-1 cannot do so because they began working for Epstein after a former employee allegedly removed the document.

persons.name: Mr. Epstein
persons.context: The defendant in the case, referred to as the employer of Employee-1 and the former employee.

connections.description: Employee-1 worked for Mr. Epstein, as referenced in the context of authenticating a document from Epstein's property.

events.title: Deadline for Government's Reply
events.description: The Government is ordered to file a reply to the Defendant's response regarding the authentication of Government Exhibit 52 by 12:00 p.m.

events.title: Deadline for Proposed Redactions
events.description: The parties are ordered to file any proposed redactions to the motion papers on the public docket, justifying them by reference to legal precedent.

keyFacts: The Defendant argues that 'Employee-1' cannot authenticate Government Exhibit 52 because a former employee (whose name is redacted) allegedly removed the document from Epstein's property before Employee-1 began working there.
The court references a prior supplemental letter from the Government (Dkt. No. 457) and a sealed response from the Defendant regarding Exhibit 52.
The order instructs the parties to justify any requested redactions using the three-part test from the Second Circuit case Lugosch v. Pyramid Co. of Onondaga.
